facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1956 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 7, 195

facts.text: Appeal from Madras High Court judgment and decree dated August 7, 1952 in A.S. No. 809 of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 7, 1952, of the Madras High Court in A. S. No. 809 of 1947, arising out of the judgment and decree dated October 31, 1947, of the Sub Judge, Tenali in 0. S. No. 64 of 1944.

facts.text: Madras High Court appeal arose from Sub Judge, Tenali judgment dated October 31, 1947 in O.S. No. 64 of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated October 31, 1947, of the Sub Judge, Tenali in 0. S. No. 64 of 1944. R. Chaudri, T. S. Venkataraman and K. B. Sharma, for the appellants. Subramanyam and T. Satyanarayana for the respondent. 1960. January 15.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on January 15, 1960 by KAPUR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. January 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-This is an appeal against the judgment and decree of the High Court of Madras varying the decree of the trial court.

facts.text: Appellants were defendants in trial court, respondent was plaintiff represented by sole trustee appointed by Hindu Religious Endowment Board.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were the defendants in the trial court and the, respondent was the plaintiff who was represented by the sole trustee appointed by the Hindu Religious Endowment Board.

facts.text: Suit brought by deity through sole trustee for recovery of Rs. 3,480 arrears of income for 1942-44.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was brought by the deity through the sole trustee for recovery of Rs. 3,480 towards the arrears of income of the property in trust for the years 1942-44 and for a direction for future payment at the rate of 160 bags of paddy per year or its equivalent i.e. Rs. 1,680.

facts.text: Plaintiff sought direction for future payment at Rs. 1,680 per year equivalent to 160 bags of paddy.

anchor.surface_text: for recovery of Rs. 3,480 towards the arrears of income of the property in trust for the years 1942-44 and for a direction for future payment at the rate of 160 bags of paddy per year or its equivalent i.e. Rs. 1,680.

facts.text: Plaintiff alleged property constituted specific endowment for Kalyanotsavam of the deity.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff alleged that the property in dispute constituted a specific endowment for Kalyanotsavam of the deity and that the defendants who were trustees had committed default in carrying out the purpose of the trust.

facts.text: Defendants committed default in carrying out purpose of trust.

anchor.surface_text: constituted a specific endowment for Kalyanotsavam of the deity and that the defendants who were trustees had committed default in carrying out the purpose of the trust. The prayer was for a decree for the recovery of expenses of Kalyanotsavam and of the feeding charges.

facts.text: Defence: inam was personal grant for driving the car of the deity on festival days, not specific endowment.

anchor.surface_text: The defence raised was that the inam was a personal grant for driving the car of the deity on the festival days and that it was not a specific trust or an endowment for the benefit of the idol.

facts.text: Defendants raised pleas of jurisdiction, res judicata, and adverse possession.

anchor.surface_text: In other words it was a grant of the inam burdened with service to the god. There were other pleas raised in regard to jurisdiction, res judicata and adverse possession.

facts.text: Trial court held grant was specific endowment for Kalyanotsavam but appellants not bound to spend whole income.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court held that the grant, was a specific endowment for the Kalyanotsavam of the deity but the appellants were not bound to spend the whole income of the lands for the purpose.

facts.text: Trial court decreed Rs. 200 per year as adequate for Kalyanotsavam.

anchor.surface_text: It decreed a sum of Rs. 200 per year as adequate provision for the performance of the service of Kalyanotsavam. The other pleas raised were decided against the appellants.

facts.text: High Court varied trial court decree, did not grant original prayer due to no proof of expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court the only point argued was regarding the nature of the grant and as in the opinion of that court a general trustee could not call upon a specific trustee to pay any money except on the ground of expending that amount and there was no proof of this expenditure the prayer as contained in the plaint was not granted

facts.text: High Court allowed amendment to plaint adding prayer for declaration that properties form specific endowment for Kalyanotsavam.

anchor.surface_text: it allowed the plaint to be amended by the addition of the prayer for a declaration that the properties in the schedule and the income thereof formed a specific endowment for the due performance of the services of Kalyanotsavam of the deity and feeding charges and other expenses incidental thereto and the appellants were therefore liable to pay the entire income.

facts.text: Supreme Court held suit was maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: As far as the first question is concerned it has not been shown as to how the suit was not maintainable.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court decision on amendment.

anchor.surface_text: The question of amendment, in our opinion, was rightly decided by the High Court. As held by that court all the necessary allegations had been made in the plaint and the requisite pleas had been raised by the appellants an issue was framed on the question and the parties were fully cognizant of the points in controversy and the necessary evidence was led by the parties.

facts.text: Both courts below found grant to be specific endowment for Kalyanotsavam based on documentary evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We then come to the question of the nature of grant which on a consideration of the documentary evidence and other evidence has been found by both the courts below to be a specific endowment for Kalyanotsavam.

facts.text: Inam statement of 1859-60 made by Buchayya, ancestor of appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The first document to be considered is of the year 1859-60 which is a copy of the inam statement made by Buchayya, the ancestor of the present appellants.

facts.text: Inam fair register dated May 16, 1860.

anchor.surface_text: The next document to be considered is a copy of the inam- fair register of May 16, 1860.

facts.text: Neither sanad nor inam title deed produced.

anchor.surface_text: From these documents and from the fact that neither the sanad nor the inam title deed was produced

facts.text: Predecessors of appellants admitted being dharmakartas of Kalyanotsavam.

anchor.surface_text: taking into consideration some admissions of the predecessors of the appellants where it was admitted that they were dharmakartas of the Kalyanotsavam and had been performing that service

facts.text: High Court and Supreme Court held inam lands were specific endowment for Kalyanotsavam.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court came to the conclusion that the inam lands in dispute were endowed for Kalyanotsavam and other purposes incidental thereto and constituted a specific trust and the appellants were trustees thereof.

facts.text: Supreme Court held whole income of inam lands to be for the deity applying cy-pres doctrine.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore justified in holding that the whole of the income was to go to deity, thus varying the judgment of the trial court that only a portion of it was to be so employed.
There were other pleas raised in regard to jurisdiction, res judicata and adverse possession.
There were other pleas raised in regard to jurisdiction, res judicata and adverse possession.
In other words it was a grant of the inam burdened with service to the god. There were other pleas raised in regard to jurisdiction,

holdings.text: The amendment of the plaint was rightly allowed by the High Court

anchor.surface_text: The question of amendment, in our opinion, was rightly decided by the High Court. As held by that court all the necessary allegations had been made in the plaint and the requisite pleas had been raised by the appellants an issue was framed on the question and the parties were fully cognizant of the points in controversy and the necessary evidence was led by the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary allegations already in plaint, pleas raised, issue framed, parties aware, evidence led; no new facts or change in cause of action

holdings.text: The grant was a specific endowment for Kalyanotsavam of the deity and constituted a specific trust; not a personal grant to the appellants

anchor.surface_text: We then come to the question of the nature of grant which on a consideration of the documentary evidence and other evidence has been found by both the courts below to be a specific endowment for Kalyanotsavam.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inam registers, statements, admissions by predecessors, and distinction in grant language indicate specific endowment; lower courts' finding upheld

holdings.text: Inam registers are evidence of the utmost importance regarding the nature of the grant

anchor.surface_text: Inam registers have always been treated as evidence of the utmost importance. The first document to be considered is of the year 1859-60

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established practice treating inam registers as primary documentary evidence

holdings.text: Language 'to be confirmed so long as the service is performed' indicates specific endowment, not personal grant
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction from Madras High Court precedents: former specific endowment, latter personal

holdings.text: The whole income of the inam lands is to be devoted to the deity under cy-pres doctrine
holdings.reasoning_summary: Original grant exhausted income on charity; increases accrue to charity per cy-pres; justified by precedents and facts from inam register

holdings.text: Pleas of jurisdiction, res judicata, and adverse possession fail

anchor.surface_text: The trial court held that the grant, was a specific endowment for the Kalyanotsavam of the deity but the appellants were not bound to spend the whole income of the lands for the purpose. It decreed a sum of Rs. 200 per year as adequate provision for the performance of the service of Kalyanotsavam. The other pleas raised were decided against the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decided against appellants by trial court; not disturbed on appeal

precedents.case_name: Hindu Religious Endowments Madras v Thadikonda Koteswara Rao
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between the words 'to be confirmed so long as the service is performed' and 'to be confirmed to the party so long as he continues the performance of the services'; the latter a personal grant and the former not
precedents.cited_holding: The latter was held to be a personal grant and the former was not so held

precedents.case_name: Hindu Religious Endowments Madras v Thadikonda Koteswara Rao
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between the words 'to be confirmed so long as the service is performed' and 'to be confirmed to the party so long as he continues the performance of the services'; the latter a personal grant and the former not

precedents.cited_proposition: when the grant was made the specific charitable payments exhausted the income of the property and [...] the intention was to devote the whole income to charity and any subsequent increase in the value of the property accrues to the charity

outcome.relief_summary: High Court judgment upheld; inam lands held to be specific endowment for Kalyanotsavam; entire income directed to be devoted to the deity and incidental purposes.
